**Harold Phil Gant**[1] (born January 10, 1940), better known as "**Handsome
Harry** ", is a retired American racecar driver best known for driving the No.
33 [Skoal Bandit](/wiki/Skoal_Bandit "Skoal Bandit") car on the
[NASCAR](/wiki/NASCAR "NASCAR") Winston Cup (now [Monster Energy NASCAR Cup
Series](/wiki/Monster_Energy_NASCAR_Cup_Series "Monster Energy NASCAR Cup
Series")) circuit during the 1980s and 1990s and his 4-race win streak in
1991.

##
Nicknames[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Harry_Gant&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Nicknames")]

Gant gained a lot of nicknames throughout his racing career. He was [known
as](/wiki/List_of_motorsports_people_by_nickname "List of motorsports people
by nickname") "Handsome Harry Gant" due to his [Hollywood](/wiki/Hollywood
"Hollywood")-style good looks, the "Bandit" after his longtime sponsor Skoal
Bandit, "Mr. September"[1] after winning four consecutive Winston Cup races
and two Busch Series races in September 1991, and "High Groove Harry" after
the high line he often took through the corner.

## Career prior to Winston
Cup[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Harry_Gant&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Career prior to Winston Cup")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/HarryGant33racecar1983.jpg/220px-
HarryGant33racecar1983.jpg)](/wiki/File:HarryGant33racecar1983.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:HarryGant33racecar1983.jpg "Enlarge")

Gant's 1983 racecar

The [North Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina "North Carolina") native began his
racing career at the old dirt track in [Hickory](/wiki/Hickory,_North_Carolina
"Hickory, North Carolina"). He built a hobby class car with his friends, and
took turns behind the wheel. Gant became the full-time driver and won the
track championship.[2] [Hickory Speedway](/wiki/Hickory_Speedway "Hickory
Speedway") was paved in 1967 after [Ned Jarrett](/wiki/Ned_Jarrett "Ned
Jarrett") became the promoter.[2] Gant excelled on the asphalt, and won his
first race in the sportsman division.

He won over 300 races with the car builder and crew chief Kenneth H. Sigmon,
in the NASCAR Sportsman on his way to winning three national championships, in
1972, 1973, and 1974. He finished second three times in the NASCAR Late Model
Sportsman (now [Nationwide Series](/wiki/Nationwide_Series "Nationwide
Series")) in 1969, 1976, and 1977. He finished in the top 10 of the final
points standing in several other years.

He sold half of his construction business in 1979 upon deciding to race full-
time in the Winston Cup Series.[2]

## Winston Cup
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Harry_Gant&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Winston Cup career")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Harry_Gant_1994.jpg/220px-
Harry_Gant_1994.jpg)](/wiki/File:Harry_Gant_1994.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Harry_Gant_1994.jpg "Enlarge")

Gant driving in 1994, his final season

Gant made his first Cup start in 1973 at Charlotte Motor Speedway, finishing
eleventh in the No. 90 [Truxmore
Industries](/w/index.php?title=Truxmore_Industries&action=edit&redlink=1
"Truxmore Industries \(page does not exist\)") Ford. He made six starts over
the next four years and had two top-ten finishes. His first full season in
Winston Cup was in 1979. He competed for the rookie of the year honors against
[Dale Earnhardt](/wiki/Dale_Earnhardt "Dale Earnhardt") and [Terry
Labonte](/wiki/Terry_Labonte "Terry Labonte"). He finished fourth in the
overall rookie battle in the No. 47 [Race Hill
Farm](/w/index.php?title=Race_Hill_Farm&action=edit&redlink=1 "Race Hill Farm
\(page does not exist\)") car for [Jack Beebe](/wiki/Jack_Beebe "Jack Beebe").
He split the next season between the No. 47 and the No. 75 [RahMoc
Enterprises](/wiki/RahMoc_Enterprises "RahMoc Enterprises") entry, finishing
21st in points.

After starting out the 1981 season driving for various teams, he moved to the
No. 33 Skoal Bandit [Pontiac](/wiki/Pontiac "Pontiac"), which was owned by
[Hal Needham](/wiki/Hal_Needham "Hal Needham") and [Burt
Reynolds](/wiki/Burt_Reynolds "Burt Reynolds"), and [Leo
Jackson](/wiki/Andy_Petree_Racing "Andy Petree Racing") after 1988. Gant
debuted with the team by placing second at [Darlington
Raceway](/wiki/Darlington_Raceway "Darlington Raceway"), followed by five more
second-place finishes and three poles, ending the season third in points
standings.[3] He stayed with the team for the rest of his career.

Gant finished second 10 times before winning his first Winston Cup race, at
Martinsville April 25, 1982, in the [Virginia National Bank
500](/wiki/Goody%27s_Cool_Orange_500 "Goody's Cool Orange 500") and he would
finish fourth in the final points standings. In 1983, Gant would only win once
at Darlington in the Transouth 400 and collect 10 top 5's and 16 top ten
finishes en route to seventh in the final points standings. In 1984, Harry
Gant notched 3 poles, 15 top five finishes, and 23 top ten finishes and won at
Pocono and Martinsville in the fall, he would end up finishing second to
eventual Winston Cup champion [Terry Labonte](/wiki/Terry_Labonte "Terry
Labonte"). In 1985, Gant would win at Martinsville in the spring, and at Dover
and at North Wilkesboro in the fall, notching a career best for Gant up to
that point. He would finish third in championship standings, 259 points behind
eventual champion Darrell Waltrip. Gant would go winless for three years from
1986-1988 and in 1989, he would break a three year winless streak winning at
Darlington in the spring which caused the veteran driver to exclaim "The
Bandit is back" in victory lane.[4]. He would not win again in 1989 but he
would finish seventh in the final points standings.

Gant won the [International Race of
Champions](/wiki/International_Race_of_Champions "International Race of
Champions") (IROC) championship in 1985.[5] He tied on points with [Darrell
Waltrip](/wiki/Darrell_Waltrip "Darrell Waltrip") but was awarded the title on
tiebreak by finishing higher in the final race: a photo-finish win over
Labonte at [Michigan International
Speedway](/wiki/Michigan_International_Speedway "Michigan International
Speedway")

Gant drove the No. 33 in the 1985 Talladega NASCAR race with the first
telemetry data system ever installed on a race car. The data from the car was
sent to the CBS television network and broadcast during the TV coverage of the
race.

## 1990's and Mr. September
streak[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Harry_Gant&action=edit&section=4&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: 1990's and Mr. September streak")]

Harry Gant entered the decade with a win at Pocono in the spring of 1990. He
would finish 17th in the final points standings with 6 top 5's and 9 top 10's.
In 1991, Gant would have a career year. He won the 1991 Winston 500 in the
spring. He gambled on fuel mileage and won. Fellow competitor Rick Mast
drafted behind Gant to give him a push the last few laps but let off in the
final laps to preserve the victory. Gant earned the nickname "Mr. September"
in 1991 after winning all four September Cup races (Darlington, Richmond,
Dover and Martinsville) and two Busch races (Richmond and Dover) at age 51.
His crew chief was [Andy Petree](/wiki/Andy_Petree "Andy Petree").[6] The four
consecutive cup victories tied the modern era record set in 1972. Dominating
at the next race at [North Wilkesboro
Speedway](/wiki/North_Wilkesboro_Speedway "North Wilkesboro Speedway"), Gant
had his brakes fail, ending his hopes of five consecutive victories[7]. Gant
would get 5 victories in 1991, and would notch 15 top five finishes and 17 top
tens and he would finish fourth in the final point standings. Gant would
follow up 1991 with a strong 1992 and finish 4th in points again and was one
of five drivers in contention for the championship but six finishes of 13th or
worse in the final races doomed his championship hopes. Gant would win at
Dover in the spring and he would get his last Cup victory on August 16, 1992,
at the [Champion Spark Plug 400](/wiki/3M_Performance_400 "3M Performance
400") at Michigan International Speedway, gambling on fuel. This would also be
the final victory for Oldsmobile in Cup competition. Harry Gant and the Leo
Jackson team would switch to Chevrolets in 1993 and at the end of the season
Gant announced that 1994 would be his last season. Gant finished his career
with a pole and seven top ten finishes and finished 25th in the final point
standings.

In 1996, Gant substituted for the injured [Bill Elliott](/wiki/Bill_Elliott
"Bill Elliott") in the 1996 [Winston Select](/wiki/NASCAR_Sprint_All-Star_Race
"NASCAR Sprint All-Star Race"), driving Elliott's No. 94
[McDonald's](/wiki/McDonald%27s "McDonald's") [Ford
Thunderbird](/wiki/Ford_Thunderbird "Ford Thunderbird") after Elliott's
injuries at Talladega.[8] Gant also ran a partial season in the Craftsman
Truck Series in 1996, driving his own No. 33 Westview Capital [Chevrolet
C/K](/wiki/Chevrolet_C/K "Chevrolet C/K"). He was inducted into the
[International Motorsports Hall of
Fame](/wiki/International_Motorsports_Hall_of_Fame "International Motorsports
Hall of Fame") on April 27, 2006.

Currently, Gant continues to work on his 300-acre ranch in North Carolina and
enjoys riding his motorcycle. In 2015, he was in attendance at Darlington for
the Southern 500 to take part in the retro weekend. He also still works on
roofs and carpentry in his spare time. Gant once admitted that he "was a good
race car driver, but a great carpenter".

## Cup
records[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Harry_Gant&action=edit&section=5&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Cup records")]

He holds the record as the oldest driver ever to win a [Cup
Series](/wiki/Sprint_Cup_Series "Sprint Cup Series") race (52 years, 219 days)
and as the oldest driver ever to collect his first career Cup victory (42
years and 105 days). He is the second oldest driver to win in NASCAR's second-
level circuit, now known as the [Xfinity Series](/wiki/Xfinity_Series "Xfinity
Series"), after [Dick Trickle](/wiki/Dick_Trickle "Dick Trickle")[9] In his
career he has collected 18 Cup wins and one runner-up finish in 1984 and third
in 1981 and 1985, 21 Busch Series wins, and three runner-up finishes in the
Busch Series championship (69, 76, and 77). In 1985 won the IROC title. He won
four races in a row in 1991 tying a "new era" (1972–present) record and came
in second in the fifth race. His five Winston Cup and five Busch Grand
National wins in 1991 made him the only driver, at that time, to post the most
wins in both series in the same year, although he tied with Davey Allison with
five Cup wins (Allison also scored a victory in the non-points All-Star Race).

## Movie
appearances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Harry_Gant&action=edit&section=6&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Movie appearances")]

He appeared in the 1983 [Burt Reynolds](/wiki/Burt_Reynolds "Burt Reynolds")
movie _[Stroker Ace](/wiki/Stroker_Ace "Stroker Ace")_. He also gave a short
interview in the film _[Days of Thunder](/wiki/Days_of_Thunder "Days of
Thunder")_ and was mentioned for spinning out in the Daytona 500 late in the
movie (although it was actually the No. 26 of [Brett
Bodine](/wiki/Brett_Bodine "Brett Bodine")). He also appeared as a mob
henchman in the 1984 movie Cannonball Run II. His line in the film was "Better
not let the boss hear you say that."
